Award.AwardTitle: Generalized Matrix Functions: Theory, Algorithms, and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
In recent years the scientific enterprise, like daily existence, has been greatly affected by the availability of new technologies that have enabled the collection of an unprecedented amount of data. This continuous creation of enormous amounts of raw digital information demands new, efficient ways to extract useful content and filter out the noise inherent in any data-gathering process. Mathematical and computational techniques of data analysis offer powerful tools that can be brought to bear, but new challenges arise on a daily basis. This requires the constant refinement and improvement of existing techniques, as well as the development of new ones. This research project aims to produce a new body of mathematical knowledge and new computational techniques that will enhance the ability to tackle challenges arising from data-intensive fields of science and engineering including computer vision, compressed sensing, control, and others. Quantitative finance, network analysis and synthesis, and medical imaging are other areas where the research can be expected to have an impact. The principal investigator will study a class of mathematical objects known as generalized matrix functions and aims to exploit the resulting knowledge to develop new, efficient computer methods for data analysis. Training of a PhD student in computational mathematics is also an integral part of the project.

The principal investigator aims to develop the theory of generalized matrix functions, a type of matrix function based on the singular value decomposition of a (possibly rectangular) matrix. The resulting theory is intended to be the basis for the development of numerical methods for the efficient approximate evaluation of such matrix functions. The focus will be primarily on large-scale problems for which the (full) singular value decomposition cannot be computed. Techniques based on sparsity and low-rank approximations will be combined with Krylov-type methods (especially the Lanczos and Golub--Kahan algorithms) to design fast algorithms for solving a variety of problems involving generalized matrix functions. The algorithms will be applied to problems such as low-rank matrix optimization, the regularization of discrete inverse problems, and the analysis of directed networks. As a by-product of this research, new algorithms for the computation of standard matrix functions where the matrix argument is only available in factored form will be derived and analyzed. This research represents a new direction in numerical linear algebra and is expected to produce useful numerical tools for the solution of a variety of problems in data science and optimization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal investigator has developed the theory of generalized matrix functions, a type of matrix function based on the singular value decomposition of a (possibly rectangular) matrix. The resulting theory lays down the basis for the development of numerical methods for the efficient approximate evaluation of such matrix functions on vectors.

Intellectual Merit: Several efficient numerical methods have been proposed to solve large-scale problems for which the (full) singular value decomposition cannot be computed. We  have  proposed  a  new  method  for  applying  generalized  matrix functions to vectors based on Chebyshev interpolation, which is matrix free and requires no orthogonalization and minimal additional storage. We later improved this method by weighted least-squares polynomial approximation based on the singular value distribution estimation and deflation techniques. We have also developed several efficient numerical methods for the fast computation of the absorption inverse and related quantities in the analysis of graphs with absorption. The performance of these algorithms have been demonstrated on problems such as the regularization of discrete inverse problems and the analysis of directed networks. The proposed methods can also be applied for standard matrix functions which has a wider range of applications. Moreover, we have proposed efficient adaptive training algorithms for learning optimal smoothers for multigrid methods in order to efficiently solve large sparse linear systems arising from partial differential equations and graph Laplacians from machine learning applications. The trained smoothers are learned on small-scale problems and can be applied to large-scale problems of the same class of problem. Numerical results on anisotropic rotated Laplacian problems and variable coefficient diffusion problems demonstrate improved convergence rates and solution time compared with classical hand-crafted smoothers.

Broader Impacts: This research project has produced a new body of mathematical knowledge and new computational techniques for tackling challenges arising from data-intensive fields of science and engineering including computer vision, compressed sensing, control, and others. Work from this project has lead to five scientific papers and one PhD student has been trained during the duration of this project.
